title: ODBC:Showing different results for the same SQL statement from ODBC vs xdmp:sql
description:
I have created a setup for database using sql-elections-5438.xml which creates a database and loads data, creates range indexes and view.

I ran the following query using xdmp:sql


xquery version "1.0-ml";
xdmp:sql('select "elections"."state" "state1" , "elections"."candidate" "candidate" , sum("elections"."votes") "votes" 
 from "usprimaries"."elections" "elections"
 group by "elections"."state", "elections"."candidate"
 order by 1 asc , 2 asc
',"format")

Result shows:
| state1| candidate| votes| 
| AL| Al Gore| 50862093| 
| AL| George W. Bush| 68897327| 
| AL| Pat Buchanan| 461141| 
| AL| Ralph Nader| 1318015| 
| AR| Al Gore| 22585284| 
| AR| George W. Bush| 25414398| 
| AR| Pat Buchanan| 591030| 
| AR| Ralph Nader| 713718| 
| AZ| Al Gore| 36872340| 
| AZ| George W. Bush| 41476496| 
| AZ| Pat Buchanan| 665724| 
| AZ| Ralph Nader| 2432346| 


| CA| Al Gore| 3113840008| 
| CA| George W. Bush| 2264343256| 
| CA| Pat Buchanan| 22774104| 
| CA| Ralph Nader| 214423584| 


I ran the same query using cognos and also using odbc client and found the following result

state	candidate	votes
AL	Al Gore	50862093
AL	George W. Bush	68897327
AL	Pat Buchanan	461141
AL	Ralph Nader	1318015
AR	Al Gore	22585284
AR	George W. Bush	25414398
AR	Pat Buchanan	591030
AR	Ralph Nader	713718
AZ	Al Gore	36872340
AZ	George W. Bush	41476496
AZ	Pat Buchanan	665724
AZ	Ralph Nader	2432346


CA	Al Gore	2147483647
CA	George W. Bush	2147483647
CA	Pat Buchanan	22774104
CA	Ralph Nader	214423584

Number votes per individual in CA are different, And I see the following xquery on the same Database show

xquery version "1.0-ml";
sum(xs:integer(doc()/Election[./State/text() = "CA" and ./Candidate/text() = "Al Gore"]/Votes/text()))

output:
3113840008

support.headline: 64 bit integer values may truncated in ODBC client
support.supportDescription: If a column in a view is defined over a 64 bit integer range index (xs:long, xs:unsignedLong) and values in that column in fact are too big to fit into a 32 bit integer, or an aggregate is run over that column whose final value is too big to fit into a 32 bit integer, the values as seen by an ODBC client will be truncated.
support.workaround: On page 2 of the advanced settings of the ODBC driver, select 'numeric' for how to treat int8. This will fix the issue with native column data, but it will not fix the issue with aggregates.

changeHistory.comment: Taking the {2|CA}  {7|Al Gore} row, the ODBC server returned the expected result, 3113840008, but by the time it gets to the Cognos display, we have 2147483647, a.k.a. 0x7FFFFFFF.  We've seen circumstantial evidence of signed/unsigned result type confusion before; this case may shed more light on that area than before.

The issue here is that the 32bit driver cannot handle integers with more than 32bits.  There are cases such as this where we do not have a specific declared type for the function and we rely on manifest typing. The column description says this is an int but the other side can't handle it and truncates.

In addition, similar behaviour can happen on long columns. Example, change the votes columns/range index to be declared as long rather than int and add:
xdmp:document-insert("dummy.xml",<Election>
	<PointOrder>6392</PointOrder>
	<Longitude>-90.858437</Longitude>
	<Latitude>29.214924</Latitude>
	<PolygonID>32094</PolygonID>
	<State>AA</State>
	<Pop_SQ_Mile>98</Pop_SQ_Mile>
	<Elected>Dummy Q. Public</Elected>
	<Candidate>Dummy Q. Public</Candidate>
	<Votes>3113840008</Votes>
	<MarginOfVictory/>
</Election>)

Then xdmp:sql('select  "elections"."state" "state1" , "elections"."candidate" "candidate" , "elections"."votes" "votes" 
 from "usprimaries"."elections" "elections" where "usprimaries"."elections"."state"="AA"','format');
will show similar mangling.

The workaround for that case is to configure the datasource to say that int8 should be treated as numeric.
Bug:20252 values duck-typed as SQLITE_INTEGER should not be shipped as int; large values will get truncated

Fixed 6.0-20130629, 1.0-20130629

You need a new version of the server and either a new version of the ODBC driver or to reconfigure the ODBC driver manually to say treat int8 as numeric (page2 of advanced settings)
Verified in the build 6.0-20130722 and looks ok to me
